articles.headline: For China, Limited Tools to Quell Unrest in Hong Kong
articles.snippet: The Chinese leader must find a solution that keeps Hong Kong stable without sparking copycat calls for change in mainland China.
articles.abstract: The Chinese leader must find a solution that keeps Hong Kong stable without sparking copycat calls for change in mainland China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s Communist Party has ample experience extinguishing unrest. For years it has used a deft mix of censorship, arrests, armed force and, increasingly, money to repress or soften calls for political change.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Armed Intruder at White House Got to East Room
articles.snippet: The man who jumped the White House fence made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent before he was tackled, a member of Congress said.
articles.abstract: The man who jumped the White House fence made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent before he was tackled, a member of Congress said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An armed man who jumped the White House fence this month made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent inside the North Portico entrance and running through the ceremonial East Room before he was tackled, according to a member of Congress familiar with the details of the incident.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built in Texas to Import Natural Gas
articles.snippet: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
articles.abstract: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SABINE PASS, Tex. — The giant Golden Pass natural gas import terminal here, meant to bring Middle Eastern gas to energy-hungry Americans, sits eerily quiet these days, a sleepy museum to a bygone era.

articles.headline: With ‘Crouching Tiger’ Sequel, Netflix Takes Aim at Hollywood
articles.snippet: Netflix and the Weinstein Company said that they planned to release a sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.
articles.abstract: Netflix and the Weinstein Company said that they planned to release a sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a first deal of its kind, Netflix and the Weinstein Company said Monday that they planned to release next year’s sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously across the globe on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Drug Patents Held Overseas Can Pare Makers’ Tax Bills
articles.snippet: While not as advantageous as an inversion, biotech players are saving on taxes by transferring patents to foreign subsidiaries.
articles.abstract: While not as advantageous as an inversion, biotech players are saving on taxes by transferring patents to foreign subsidiaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration tries to stop companies from avoiding taxes by moving their headquarters overseas, the makers of some of the world’s most lucrative and expensive medicines are using another tactic to reduce their payments to the government.

articles.headline: Many Missteps in Assessment of ISIS Threat
articles.snippet: The question of how officials failed to anticipate the rise of ISIS resonates inside and outside the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The question of how officials failed to anticipate the rise of ISIS resonates inside and outside the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By late last year, classified American intelligence reports painted an increasingly ominous picture of a growing threat from Sunni extremists in Syria, according to senior intelligence and military officials. Just as worrisome, they said, were reports of deteriorating readiness and morale among troops next door in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: The Big Dangers of Fighting Bad Press
articles.snippet: A lawsuit filed by Stephen A. Wynn, the casino impresario, against an investor he accused of slandering him is the latest salvo in the growing tensions between vocal shareholders and corporations.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit filed by Stephen A. Wynn, the casino impresario, against an investor he accused of slandering him is the latest salvo in the growing tensions between vocal shareholders and corporations.

articles.headline: Revisiting the Lehman Brothers Bailout That Never Was
articles.snippet: New accounts of events in 2008 as the New York Fed assessed the bank’s eligibility for rescue from bankruptcy have cast the firm’s collapse in a new light.
articles.abstract: New accounts of events in 2008 as the New York Fed assessed the bank’s eligibility for rescue from bankruptcy have cast the firm’s collapse in a new light.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, time was running out to answer a question that would change Wall Street forever.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Europeans Accuse Ireland of Giving Apple Illegal Tax Break
articles.snippet: A commission laid out its preliminary case over Apple’s taxes in Ireland, and it told the country it may order it to collect huge amounts of back taxes.
articles.abstract: A commission laid out its preliminary case over Apple’s taxes in Ireland, and it told the country it may order it to collect huge amounts of back taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a warning shot to companies shopping for tax deals around the globe, the European Commission publicly accused Ireland on Tuesday of giving illegal subsidies to Apple and cautioned that the country might need to collect back taxes from the company, which outside analysts said could reach into the billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and James Kanter

articles.headline: EBay Does About-Face in Spinoff of PayPal Backed by Icahn
articles.snippet: The board of directors long resisted calls by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn to separate from PayPal, which generates almost half of eBay’s revenue.
articles.abstract: The board of directors long resisted calls by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn to separate from PayPal, which generates almost half of eBay’s revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: At eBay’s annual board retreat in Half Moon Bay, Calif., in June, the company’s 12 directors found themselves moving in a somewhat unexpected direction: breaking up the company just as the hedge fund billionaire Carl C. Icahn had suggested.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Hong Kong Protests Are Leaderless but Orderly
articles.snippet: The crowds on the streets maintain fastidious attention to hygiene and good manners as they rally for democracy.
articles.abstract: The crowds on the streets maintain fastidious attention to hygiene and good manners as they rally for democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — They sleep by the thousands on what are normally the busiest boulevards of this crammed, nonstop city. They live on crackers, bananas and bottled water. They clean up their trash, even taking the time to pick out plastic and paper for recycling. Their shield of choice, and the symbol of their cause, is the umbrella: protection against the sun, rain — and pepper spray used by the riot police.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy

articles.headline: Lawmakers Rebuke Secret Service Chief Over White House Breach
articles.snippet: Members of Congress raised doubts that Julia Pierson, the agency’s director, was the right person to confront what they called systemic problems and a lack of candor about recent breaches.
articles.abstract: Members of Congress raised doubts that Julia Pierson, the agency’s director, was the right person to confront what they called systemic problems and a lack of candor about recent breaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress declared Tuesday that they had lost confidence in the Secret Service to protect President Obama and his family and raised serious doubts that Julia Pierson, the director of the agency, was the right person to confront what they called systemic problems and a striking lack of candor about recent security breaches.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Doctors Find Barriers to Sharing Digital Medical Records
articles.snippet: Doctors and hospital executives are expressing frustration that high expense and technical difficulties inhibit a major goal of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Doctors and hospital executives are expressing frustration that high expense and technical difficulties inhibit a major goal of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a practicing ear, nose and throat specialist in Ahoskie, N.C., Dr. Raghuvir B. Gelot says that little has frustrated him more than the digital record system he installed a few years ago.
